column1: 23155421_7,s1,T13,T14,"First, it has been shown that by forcing the TMD and TIR domains of ",TLRs," to be in a dimeric complex using constitutively dimeric extracellular domains, it is possible to activate the ",NF-kappaB, pathway as well as other known TLR gene promoters in the absence of ligands.,Not_a_complex

23155421_7,s1,T13,T15,"First, it has been shown that by forcing the TMD and TIR domains of ",TLRs," to be in a dimeric complex using constitutively dimeric extracellular domains, it is possible to activate the NF-kappaB pathway as well as other known ",TLR, gene promoters in the absence of ligands.,Not_a_complex

23155421_7,s1,T14,T15,"First, it has been shown that by forcing the TMD and TIR domains of TLRs to be in a dimeric complex using constitutively dimeric extracellular domains, it is possible to activate the ",NF-kappaB, pathway as well as other known ,TLR, gene promoters in the absence of ligands.,Not_a_complex

23155421_7,s3,T2,T3,"Third, structural modeling using the ",TLR3, extracellular domain and ,TLR10, TIR domain suggested a close proximity between TMD domains in the dimeric complex that could allow for the TMD region to associate.,Complex_formation

23155421_7,s4,T4,T5,"Last, recent studies on ",TLR4," have demonstrated the importance of the tight coupling of the extracellular domain and TIR domain to the TMD as a requirement for signaling, and that the ",TLR4, extracellular domain prevents constitutive dimeric activation of TLR4 in the absence of ligand.,Not_a_complex

23155421_7,s4,T4,T6,"Last, recent studies on ",TLR4," have demonstrated the importance of the tight coupling of the extracellular domain and TIR domain to the TMD as a requirement for signaling, and that the TLR4 extracellular domain prevents constitutive dimeric activation of ",TLR4, in the absence of ligand.,Not_a_complex

23155421_7,s4,T5,T6,"Last, recent studies on TLR4 have demonstrated the importance of the tight coupling of the extracellular domain and TIR domain to the TMD as a requirement for signaling, and that the ",TLR4, extracellular domain prevents constitutive dimeric activation of ,TLR4, in the absence of ligand.,Not_a_complex

23155421_7,s5,T16,T17,Based on these findings and the fact that the ,TLRs, are single pass membrane proteins that are known to form functional homo- and heterodimers we asked the question if TLR TMDs are capable of oligomerization in a manner analogous to the native ,TLRs,.,Not_a_complex

23155421_7,s5,T16,T18,Based on these findings and the fact that the ,TLRs, are single pass membrane proteins that are known to form functional homo- and heterodimers we asked the question if ,TLR, TMDs are capable of oligomerization in a manner analogous to the native TLRs.,Not_a_complex

23155421_7,s6,T7,T21,"Interestingly, such a hypothesis is also supported by the fact that for the two pairs of heterodimeric TLRs (",TLR2,/,1,", TLR2/6), the transmembrane domain sequences of TLR1 and TLR6 are almost identical (Table 1) due to recent evolutionary divergence, suggesting that their TMD regions possibly contribute to their association with TLR2.",Complex_formation

23155421_7,s6,T21,T22,"Interestingly, such a hypothesis is also supported by the fact that for the two pairs of heterodimeric TLRs (TLR2/",1,", TLR2/",6,"), the transmembrane domain sequences of TLR1 and TLR6 are almost identical (Table 1) due to recent evolutionary divergence, suggesting that their TMD regions possibly contribute to their association with TLR2.",Not_a_complex

23155421_7,s6,T7,T11,"Interestingly, such a hypothesis is also supported by the fact that for the two pairs of heterodimeric TLRs (",TLR2,"/1, TLR2/6), the transmembrane domain sequences of TLR1 and TLR6 are almost identical (Table 1) due to recent evolutionary divergence, suggesting that their TMD regions possibly contribute to their association with ",TLR2,.,Not_a_complex

23155421_7,s6,T20,T7,"Interestingly, such a hypothesis is also supported by the fact that for the two pairs of heterodimeric ",TLRs, (,TLR2,"/1, TLR2/6), the transmembrane domain sequences of TLR1 and TLR6 are almost identical (Table 1) due to recent evolutionary divergence, suggesting that their TMD regions possibly contribute to their association with TLR2.",Not_a_complex

23155421_7,s6,T7,T22,"Interestingly, such a hypothesis is also supported by the fact that for the two pairs of heterodimeric TLRs (",TLR2,"/1, TLR2/",6,"), the transmembrane domain sequences of TLR1 and TLR6 are almost identical (Table 1) due to recent evolutionary divergence, suggesting that their TMD regions possibly contribute to their association with TLR2.",Not_a_complex

23155421_7,s6,T7,T8,"Interestingly, such a hypothesis is also supported by the fact that for the two pairs of heterodimeric TLRs (",TLR2,"/1, ",TLR2,"/6), the transmembrane domain sequences of TLR1 and TLR6 are almost identical (Table 1) due to recent evolutionary divergence, suggesting that their TMD regions possibly contribute to their association with TLR2.",Not_a_complex

23155421_7,s7,T23,T24,Our results demonstrate that isolated ,TLR, TMDs are indeed capable of oligomerizing and have higher propensity for ,TLR, interactions previously identified.,Not_a_complex
